DOC.HEAD: Soviet Foreign Minister Makes Unprecedented Visit To NATO Headquarters

Eds: LEADS with 15 grafs to UPDATE with further Shevardnadze comments to European Parliament, U.S. official's comment on Eastern Europe; Picks up 15th graf, `Shevardnadze's visit ...'; SUBS grafs 21-31, `The report ...' with 5 grafs to tighten, include further comments.
DOC.TEXT: Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze made an unprecedented visit to NATO headquarters today and said the Warsaw Pact and NATO must remain in place despite sharply reduced East-West tensions. Later, he reiterated Soviet concerns about German reunification and warned Western nations not to pressure the German states to come together. ``We do believe the Warsaw Treaty and NATO at this crucial stage in European development ... are able to play a very important stabilizing role to become a stabilizing factor in Europe,'' Shevardnadze told reporters after meeting NATO Secretary-General Manfred Woerner. Woerner said Shevardnadze ``mentioned the very essential role of the Americans here in Europe'' and that the Soviet envoy expressed interest in setting up formal links between the two military alliances. Woerner said he told Shevardnadze the Warsaw Pact would have to make further changes before such a move could be considered. It was the first time such a high Soviet official has been to NATO headquarters. His visit came a day after the Western alliance issued a report saying the Soviet Union appears to be cutting defense spending. Both officials said they agreed that an accord could be wrapped up next year on reducing conventional weapons in Europe. They also agreed a superpower agreement could be worked out next year on reducing long-range nuclear weapons. ``My impression is that the Cold War is, indeed, over,'' Shevardnadze said later during a speech to members of the European Parliament. During the speech, he welcomed the fact that Western leaders have endorsed reunification if favored by both East and West Germany but added, ``Any appeals or advice `to exercise self-determination' or prescriptions as to how and when to change the ... system of government are not only inappropriate, but may raise doubts about the authenticity of the eventual allegedly free choice.'' Shevardnadze said there are two good reasons to oppose reunification: ``We (the Soviet Union) paid the price of 20 million lives for the existing European stability,'' he said of World War II. ``Furthermore, can the German people themselves forget the national tragedy brought onto them by Hitlerism?'' Separately, U.S. Gen. John Galvin, NATO's military commander in Europe, called events in Eastern Europe an ``enormous transition (that) is fraught with potential dangers of instability and uncertainty.'' ``In the face of this, a unified NATO can be very helpful, and it appears the Soviets recognize this as well,'' Galvin said in a statement. Shevardnadze's visit to NATO was viewed as carrying great symbolic importance at a time of a rapidly changing East-West climate. On Monday, NATO released a study that said the Soviet Union appears to have begun cutting its defense expenditures, including in the critical area of conventional forces. The analysis offers new evidence that the Kremlin is trying to pare down its massive military industry. A year ago, Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev went before the United Nations and promised to unilaterally cut Soviet forces by 500,000 troops and reduce conventional arms substantially. A month later, he called for a 14.2 percent cut in military spending and a 19.5 percent reduction in military production. ``A number of major procurement programs, particularly in the land armaments area, are being scaled back,'' the NATO report says. It adds, however, that it is too early to tell whether all of Gorbachev's promises will be carried out. To the European Parliament, Shevardnadze outlined at length his concerns about German reunification. ``Where are the political, legal and material guarantees that German unity would not eventually create a threat to the national security of other states and to peace in Europe?'' he asked. ``Will such a hypothetical Germany ... be ready to accept the existing borders in Europe and renounce any territorial claims? As we know, the government of the Federal republic of Germany has avoided answering that question.'' Europe, he said, must have two ``sovereign German states ... A retreat from that is fraught with destabilization in Europe.'' Shevardnadze later flew to London for talks with Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher. He made no statement upon arriving at the airport.
